edge: The film's exploration of Asian American identity incorporates nihilism, as discussed by Anne Anlin Cheng in The New Yorker. This relationship highlights the tension between the oppressive force of cultural assimilation and the potential for resistance through embracing one's heritage.

According to Laura Zornosa from The New York Times, Everything Everywhere All at Once addresses intergenerational trauma through healing relationships. This relationship underscores the film's emphasis on familial bonds and the potential for reconciliation.

A.O. Scott from The New York Times describes Everything Everywhere All at Once as a 'swirl of genre anarchy.' This relationship highlights the film's eclectic mix of genres, including surreal comedy, science fiction, fantasy, martial arts films, and animation.

A.O. Scott from The New York Times also notes that while the film's action sequences and science-fiction elements are entertaining, they are not its primary focus. Instead, he argues that it is 'a bittersweet domestic drama' and a 'hurt-filled ballad of mother-daughter love.'

Emily St. James from Vox describes Everything Everywhere All at Once as part of a new subgenre of 'millennial parental apology fantasy.' This relationship highlights the film's exploration of intergenerational relationships and reconciliation.

The film's exploration of Asian American identity incorporates nihilism, as Anne Anlin Cheng describes in The Washington Post. This is not just a metaphor or parable for the dislocations and personality splits suffered by hyphenated citizens but also becomes a vehicle for confronting and negotiating Asian-pessimism.

The multiverse acts as a metaphor for the immigrant Asian experience, according to Anne Anlin Cheng in The Washington Post. This is not just a convenient parable for the dislocations and personality splits suffered by hyphenated citizens but also becomes a vehicle for confronting and negotiating Asian-pessimism.

Daniels weaves the chaotic possibilities into the multiverse into a cohesive story about the travails of the road not traveled and the need to carve out your own meaning in a meaningless universe, according to Clint Worthington's description of Jobu Tupaki's modus operandi.
The everything bagel concept allows us to talk about nihilism without being too eye roll-y and creates a MacGuffin: a doomsday device, according to Kwan's explanation.
In the second half of the movie, people realize that the everything bagel is not here to destroy the world but a depressed person trying to destroy themselves, as described by Kwan.
The writer George Gillett argues that the movie is 'a coming-of-age film for the internet generation'
The multiverse in the movie resembles virtual environments which viewers increasingly exist within, as viewed by George Gillett
Waymond's belief that people should 'be kind, especially when we don't know what's going on' is an expression of the central ideas of humanism
The recurring images of the bagel and the googly eyes are described as 'a surprisingly apt and humorous take on yin and yang'
One version of Evelyn in the movie is a portrayal of Yeoh
Quan's experience as a stunt coordinator is used diegetically in Waymond's fight scenes

node_2: a more sinister, english-fluent, machiavellian strategist
edge: In the film Big Trouble in Little China (1986), James Hong portrayed a character named Lo Pan. In the given context, it is mentioned that Hong's transformation into 'a more sinister, English-fluent, Machiavellian strategist' parallels his character Lo Pan in Big Trouble in Little China. This shows that the new persona of James Hong can be seen as an extension or advanced version of his character Lo Pan with added traits such as sinisterness and proficiency in English.
